selection_rationale: Under label noise, the one-sided projector dimension (subspace_ratio r/d) controls how much gradient signal is retained versus filtered; the learning rate (lr) directly affects stability of updates in the presence of corrupted labels; batch_size determines gradient variance reduction via averaging, improving robustness against label flips.

configs.rationale: Strong projection (smaller r/d) with moderate lr and a larger batch to aggressively filter noisy components while maintaining learning speed.
Slightly larger subspace with conservative lr to enhance stability; batch_size 64 reduces gradient variance from label noise.
Moderate projection with a bigger batch to counteract noise and stabilize updates; keeps lr moderate for faster convergence.
Baseline-like r/d but slightly reduced lr relative to default, plus larger batch to test if projection at standard dimension remains robust.
Higher r/d to retain more signal, balanced by moderate lr and enlarged batch to keep noisy gradients in check.
Aggressive filtering with small r/d paired with higher lr, compensated by very large batch to dampen noise-induced instability.
Large subspace approaching full space but with conservative lr to avoid amplifying noise; batch 64 provides variance reduction.
Very conservative lr for maximum stability under noise, with moderate r/d and larger batch to ensure steady progress.

expected_improvement: We expect lower training loss and higher test accuracy under 20% label flips by reducing lr (≈0.10–0.12), increasing batch_size (64–128), and selecting a moderate projection (subspace_ratio≈0.15–0.30), yielding more stable gradients and better robustness for SFedAvg.
